APPLICATION MOLCAA 8353 S1381-1169(12)00041-6 10.1016/j.molcata.2012.01.021 Elsevier B.V. Scheme 1 Preparation of S-2 catalyst. Scheme 2 Reaction between Phillips catalyst and TPS. Scheme 3 Reaction between HMDS and (A) residual hydroxyl groups on the surface of catalyst and (B) TPS. Scheme 4 Plausible mechanism of the formation of two kinds of Cr active site precursors on HCat-2 catalyst with simultaneous interaction with TEA and monomer: y =1 or 2 and m or n =1 or 2. Fig. 1 TGA curves of different chromium catalysts before and after reacting with HMDS. (a) Phillips, (b) HCat-1, (c) HCat-2, (d) HCat-3, and (e) S-2. Fig. 2 IR spectrums of different chromium catalysts after reacting with HMDS. (a) Phillips, (b) HCat-1, (c) HCat-2, (d) HCat-3, and (e) S-2. Fig. 3 Ethylene polymerization activities of HCat-2 catalyst with different dosages of cocatalyst. Conditions: catalyst 70mg, ethylene 0.14MPa, n-heptane 70mL, 90°C, 1h. Fig. 4 Kinetic curves of ethylene polymerization by using HCat-2 catalyst with different cocatalysts at ethylene pressure of 0.14MPa. Fig. 5 GPC curves of ethylene polymers obtained from HCat-2 catalyst with different cocatalysts at ethylene pressure of 0.14MPa. (a) TEA, (b) TIBA, and (c) MAO. Fig. 6 Kinetic curves of ethylene polymerization with different chromium catalysts at ethylene pressure of 0.14MPa. Fig. 7 GPC curves of polymers obtained from different chromium catalysts at ethylene pressure of 0.3MPa. (a) Phillips, (b) HCat-1, (c) HCat-2, (d) HCat-3, (e) S-2, and (f) Cat-M. Fig. 8 GPC curves of ethylene/1-hexene copolymers obtained from different chromium catalysts at ethylene pressure of 0.14MPa. (a) Phillips, (b) HCat-1, (c) HCat-2, (d) HCat-3, (e) S-2, and (f) Cat-M. Fig. 9 DSC curves of ethylene/1-hexene copolymers obtained from different chromium catalysts at ethylene pressure of 0.14MPa. (a) Phillips, (b) HCat-1, (c) HCat-2, (d) HCat-3, (e) S-2, and (f) Cat-M. Fig. 10 GPC curves of ethylene polymers obtained from HCat-2 catalyst with different polymerization temperatures at ethylene pressure of 0.3MPa. (a) 70°C, (b) 80°C, and (c) 90°C. A novel SiO2-supported inorganic and organic hybrid chromium-based catalyst for ethylene polymerization Shiliang Zhang a Qi Dong a Ruihua Cheng a Xuelian He a ⁎ Quntao Wang b Yan Tang b Yongling Yu b Kan Xie b Jianwen Da b Boping Liu a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, No. 130 Meilong Road, Xuhui District, Shanghai 200237, China b Research Institute of Qilu Branch Co., SINOPEC, Zibo 255400, Shandong, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 021 64253627; fax: +86 021 64253627. Graphical abstract A novel SiO2-supported inorganic and organic hybrid chromium-based catalyst for ethylene polymerization was prepared by using the residual surface hydroxyl groups in Phillips catalyst to further support bis(triphenysilyl) chromate. Highlights ► A novel SiO2-supported chromium-based catalyst for ethylene polymerization. ► Hybridizing inorganic Phillips and organic S-2 catalysts. ► Suitable calcination temperature ≤600°C and total Cr loading ≤0.5wt%. ► Proper addition amount of organic bis(triphenysilyl) chromate was CrBC ≤0.25wt%. ► Effects of cocatalyst, temperature, pressure and hydrogen on polymerization. In this work, a novel SiO2-supported hybrid chromium-based catalyst for ethylene and ethylene/1-hexene polymerization was prepared by using the residual surface hydroxyl groups in Phillips catalyst to further support bis(triphenysilyl) chromate (BC) in order to get the merits from two important chromium-based catalysts namely inorganic Phillips and organic S-2 catalysts. By characterization of the catalysts, investigation of the polymerization behavior and the microstructures of polymers, several vital factors such as cocatalyst, the addition amount of BC, calcination temperature, total chromium loading, polymerization temperature, pressure and hydrogen were systematically investigated. The proper addition weight amount of BC was CrBC ≤0.25wt%. The suitable calcination temperature and total chromium loading were ≤600°C and ≤0.5wt%, respectively. With increasing the relative addition amount of CrBC from 0 to 20, 50, 80 and 100wt% (corresponding from Phillips to HCat-1, HCat-2, HCat-3 and S-2 catalysts), the copolymerization abilities of the above catalysts showed a decreasing tendency. By comparing different chromium catalysts, HCat-2 catalyst showed higher activity than S-2 catalyst and its polymer had higher average molecular weight (MW) than that obtained from Phillips catalyst. HCat-2 catalyst got well-balanced properties mainly including activity, MW of polymers and copolymerization ability. Keywords Phillips CrO x /SiO2 catalyst S-2 catalyst Inorganic and organic hybrid chromium-based catalyst Ethylene polymerization 1 Introduction Two traditional chromium-based catalysts including inorganic Phillips catalyst and organic S-2 catalyst are widely used as important industrial catalyst to manufacture commercial polyethylene products for various applications such as packing films, containers, automobile parts and pipe materials, which account for nearly 40% polyethylene resins in the world market [1]. The two catalysts have their own unique features on ethylene polymerization performance and polyethylene products. Traditional Phillips catalyst patented by Hogan and Banks in 1958 [2] is usually prepared by impregnating aqueous solution of chromium compounds (mostly chromium (III) acetate) onto amorphous silica gel support followed by calcination in dry air at usually 500–900°C for several hours. It is often applied to produce commercial high destiny polyethylene (HDPE) with relatively high molecular weight (MW), broad molecular weight distribution (MWD) and a few long chain branches in the global market. In more than 50 year's history of investigating Phillips catalyst, lots of literatures, which included several important literature reviews published by Hogan [3], McDaniel [4–6] and Zecchina [7], have been published on the ethylene polymerization behavior and mechanism of this catalyst and the features of its polymer, etc. In recent years, many new literatures were published about the latest achievements in this field [1,8–15], many of which focused on the modification of the Phillips catalyst [12–15]. In this aspect, although there were some different methods reported in the previous literatures, the main modification of the Phillips catalyst was usually focused on its support, which mainly included the modification of silica gel support with other elements [16,17] and substituting silica gel with other support materials [18]. McDaniel et al. [4,19] once used their coprecipitated silica–titania support to prepare Cr/silica–titania catalyst for ethylene polymerization, and found that the presence of Ti could shorten the induction period, enhance both the activity and melt index (MI) response. Johnson et al. [20–22] substituted silica gel with aluminophosphate as support to prepare Cr/AlPO4 catalyst for ethylene polymerization, and found that the catalyst showed much shorter induction period, higher activity and produced the polymer with relatively lower MW compared with traditional Cr/SiO2 catalyst. On the other hand, S-2 catalyst patented by Union Carbide Corporation (UCC) is another successful commercial chromium-based catalyst and still applied to produce HDPE products until now. It is mainly synthesized by chemisorption of bis(triphenysilyl) chromate (BC) on dehydrated silica gel as shown in Scheme 1 and also shows relatively high activity for ethylene polymerization [23–25]. However, compared with those of Phillips catalyst, literatures about the investigation of S-2 catalyst were much less. Baker and Carrick once investigated the S-2 catalyst in many aspects such as cocatalyst, polymerization temperature and silica gel type [26,27]. Cann et al. [28,29] compared S-2 catalyst with Phillips catalyst in the absence of cocatalyst and found that S-2 catalyst showed longer induction period, lower activity and less comonomer incorporation, but its HDPE products have slightly higher MW and broader MWD. Nevertheless the literatures concerning the modification of S-2 catalyst were much less than those of Phillips catalyst. Only in several patents [24], Baker et al. reported that they used Al2O3 or SiO2/Al2O3 to support BC for the preparation of commercial S-2 catalyst for producing HDPE. Hence it could be summarized that the modification of Phillips and S-2 catalysts was mostly focused on the modification of their supports. Later on, several new literatures were published about preparing SiO2-supported organic chromium-based catalysts for ethylene polymerization from Phillips catalyst. Cann et al. [28,29] introduced triphenylsilanol (TPS) into Phillips catalyst system and found the conversion reaction from Phillips catalyst to S-2 catalyst as shown in Scheme 2 . We [30] continued to investigate this method in several aspects such as the proper dosage of TPS and the effect of hydroxyl group through experiment and computational simulation. Fang et al. [31] also used the reaction between chromate and silanol to prepare a novel organic chromium-based catalyst for ethylene polymerization by introducing methyl(1-naphthyl)phenylsilanol ligand into Phillips catalyst system. On the other hand, a few literatures were also published on the hybrid of different chromium-based catalysts [32,33] and chromium-based catalyst with non-chromium based catalyst to prepare supported hybrid chromium-based catalysts. Kurek et al. [34] prepared a novel mesoporous silica gel to support a post-metallocene chromium complex and a half sandwich chromium complex to prepare a novel hybrid catalyst for producing polyethylene with ultra-broad MWD. Moreno et al. [35–37] synthesized a novel silica–alumina–SBA-15 material for the supporting of chromium (III) nitrate and metallocene zirconium complex to prepare chromium oxide/metallocene hybrid catalyst for producing bimodal polyethylene. Nevertheless, much more work has been published on the hybridizing of another two famous industrious catalysts namely Ziegler–Natta and metallocene catalysts by various methods such as the preparation of bisupport [38,39]. However, the hybridization of Phillips and S-2 catalysts had never been reported in the literatures. Since the two catalysts are both important industrial chromium-based catalysts and have their own unique features on ethylene polymerization performance and polyethylene products as described above, it is reasonable to hybridize the two catalysts in order to get the merits from each catalyst system. In this work, we hybridized Phillips and S-2 catalysts by using the residual hydroxyl groups on the surface of the Phillips catalyst to prepare a novel SiO2-supported hybrid chromium-based catalyst for ethylene and ethylene/1-hexene polymerization. By characterizing the catalysts, investigating the polymerization behavior and the microstructures of polymers, several vital factors such as cocatalyst, the addition amount of BC, calcination temperature, total chromium (Crtotal) loading, polymerization temperature, pressure and hydrogen, which could influence the properties of the hybrid catalyst system, were systematically investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Raw materials The gas used in this work including high purity nitrogen (N2 ≥99.999%), high purity hydrogen (H2 ≥99.999%) and high purity dry air (Total impurity <1ppm, dew point of H2O<−80°C) were purchased from Shanghai Wetry Criterion Gas Co., Ltd. The nitrogen used in the catalyst preparation, ethylene and ethylene/1-hexene polymerization at atmospheric pressure was further purified by passing through one column of 4A molecular sieves (purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) as moisture scavenger and one column of sliver molecular sieves (28wt% of silver (I) oxide on alumina, purchased from Sigma–Aldrich.) as oxygen scavenger. Ethylene monomer (polymerization grade) donated from Shanghai Branch Co., SINOPEC was purified by subsequently passing through three columns of 4A molecular sieves, Q-5 reactant catalyst (13wt% of copper (II) oxide on alumina, purchased from Sigma–Aldrich as oxygen scavenger.) and 13× molecular sieves (purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. as moisture scavenger.) for ethylene and ethylene/1-hexene polymerization at atmospheric pressure. The gases for ethylene polymerization at high pressure including high purity nitrogen and ethylene monomer were directly purified by a commercial gas purification equipment, which was purchased from Dalian Samat Chemicals Co., Ltd. Each gas was purified by passing through two large columns filled with different molecular sieves as moisture and oxygen scavengers. Chromium (III) acetate hydroxide of assay grade (CAH, 24wt% Cr), diphenyl ketone (AR grade) and hydrochloric acid (HCl, AR grade) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Bis(triphenysilyl) chromate (BC, total purity BC≥95%) and silica gel (Grace Davison 955, surface 270.4m2/g, pore volume 1.65cm3/g and average pore size 24.5nm) were donated from Qilu Branch Co., SINOPEC. All the solvents including n-hexane (AR grade) and n-heptane (AR grade), which were also purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., were first purified by 4A molecular sieves and subsequently purged through distillation in the presence of sodium metal slices and diphenyl ketone as indicator until the indicator showed pure blue before use or for storage in a stainless-steel storage tank under purified nitrogen atmosphere. Triisobutylaluminium (TIBA, 0.986M in hexane) and triethylaluminium (TEA, 1.82M in hexane) was purchased from Alfa Aesar. Methylaluminoxane (MAO, 1.5M solution in toluene) and 1-hexene (Total purity 97%) as comonomer were purchased from J&K Chemical Co. 1-Hexene was also purged through distillation in the presence of sodium and diphenyl ketone until the indicator showed pure blue before use. Hexamethyldisilazane (HMDS, ≥99.0% GC) was purchased from Sigma–Aldrich. 2.2 Catalyst preparation About 10g silica gel was impregnated with aqueous solution of chromium (III) acetate hydroxide by stirring for 4h before dryness at 120°C for 12h. After impregnation, the catalyst precursors were calcined at 600°C for 5h under a flow rate of 600mL/min high purity dry air in a fluidized-bed quartz reactor with a temperature-programmed heating controller and electric furnace around it. Then it was cooled down to 350°C under dry air followed by further cooling down to room temperature under nitrogen atmosphere. The catalyst was transferred into a glove box for storage. About 8g Phillips catalyst was used to support BC by using 150mL purified n-hexane as solvent to dissolve BC followed by stirring at 45°C for 4h under nitrogen atmosphere. Thereafter, the solvent was completely removed by drying at 80°C for at least 4h under nitrogen atmosphere to prepare the hybrid catalyst. The catalyst was transferred into glove box for storage before use. Herein, three hybrid catalysts with 0.5wt% Crtotal loading were prepared in this way by adding different weight amount of CrBC including 0.10wt%, 0.25wt% and 0.40wt%. The three catalysts were named as HCat-1, HCat-2 and HCat-3 catalysts according to the weight amount ratio between CrBC and Crtotal in each catalyst including 20wt%, 50wt% and 80wt%, respectively. This weight amount ratio was further defined as the relative addition amount of CrBC. For comparison, a traditional Phillips catalyst with 0.5wt% Crtotal loading calcined at 600°C was also prepared in the same way as mentioned above and a S-2 catalyst with 0.5wt% Crtotal loading was prepared by directly supporting BC on a pretreated silica gel. The pretreatment of silica gel for supporting BC is shown as follows. About 10g silica gel support was first dehydrated at 600°C and a flow rate of 600mL/min under nitrogen atmosphere in the fluidized-bed quartz reactor as mentioned above to keep for 5h and then cooled down to room temperature under nitrogen atmosphere. About 8g pretreated silica gel was used to support BC in the same way as mentioned above to prepare the S-2 catalyst. Moreover, a mechanically mixed catalyst with a mixing weight ratio of 1:1 between the Phillips and S-2 catalysts named as Cat-M was prepared by mechanically mixing the two catalysts with 0.5wt% Crtotal loading in the glove box before use. The Cat-M catalyst was used to compare with the HCat-2 catalyst. For a comparison with the HCat-1 catalyst, another three hybrid catalysts were also prepared in the same way as mentioned above except the variations in calcination temperature and Crtotal loading. All the relative addition amount of CrBC of the three catalysts were keeping at 20wt%, and two of them were calcined at 500°C and 700°C with 0.5wt% Crtotal loading and named as HCat-11 and HCat-12 catalysts, respectively. The other one named as HCat-13 catalyst was calcined at 600°C with 1.0wt% Crtotal loading. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts 2.3.1 Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) characterization In order to confirm the fully supporting of BC on the surface of silica gel, ICP characterization of the prepared catalysts was performed with or without a washing treatment. The washing of the catalyst sample was described as follows. About 1g catalyst sample was washed for three times by using 40mL purified n-hexane as solvent to dissolve BC under purified nitrogen atmosphere in a Schlenk bottle with a magnetic stirrer. Thereafter, the solvent was completely removed by drying at 80°C for at least 2h under purified nitrogen atmosphere, and the sample was stored in glove box. Then, about 25mg catalyst samples before and after washing were weighted in glove box and then dissolved by HCl solution to prepare each sample (sample concentration: about 2.5mgCat/mL). The Crtotal loading of each sample was measured by ICP spectrometer (Vanan 710). In this work, the relative Cr loading loss after washing was defined as follows. Relative Cr loading loss after washing=(Crtotal loading after preparation−Crtotal loading after washing)/Crtotal loading after preparation×100%. 2.3.2 TGA–DTA and FTIR characterizations Before TGA–DTA and the subsequent FTIR characterizations, the catalyst sample was treated as follows. About 160mg catalyst sample was weighted and reacted with 0.774g HMDS in a small Schlenk bottle under purified nitrogen atmosphere at 175°C for 10h, then purged by purified nitrogen for 2h at 175°C to remove unreacted HMDS. Then, about 7mg catalyst samples before and after the reacting with HMDS were weighted and heated to 700°C at 10°C/min under air at 10mL/min. The TGA–DTA curve of each sample was recorded by a thermal analyzer (TA, SDT Q600). About 10mg catalyst sample after reacting with HMDS was weighted, mixed with KBr (sample:KBr=1:100, w/w) and pressed into a small sample disc for scanning by FTIR spectrometer (Thermo Fisher, Nicolet 5700) with 2cm−1 resolution and 24 accumulation cycles to record IR spectroscopy. 2.4 Ethylene, ethylene/1-hexene polymerization and characterization of polymers In this work, the semi-batch slurry polymerization mode was utilized for ethylene and ethylene/1-hexene polymerization at both atmospheric and high pressure. In ethylene and ethylene/1-hexene polymerization at atmospheric pressure, one small ampoule tube with about 160mg catalysts, which was previously weighted and sealed in the glove box, was transferred to a 250mL three-necked flask immerged in a silicone oil bath with thermostat keeping at 90°C. The reactor system was first heated in vacuum and purged by nitrogen for at least three times for 0.5h, then purged by ethylene monomer for one time and finally full of monomer until the ethylene pressure was about 0.12MPa. Then 70mL n-heptane, a certain amount of cocatalyst such as TEA (Al/Cr molar ratio at 10–30), TIBA (Al/Cr molar ratio at 10–30) or MAO (Al/Cr molar ratio at 30–150) and 10mL hydrogen or 2.1mL 1-hexene if necessary were subsequently injected into the flask with magnetically stirring. Until the solution was saturated at the ethylene pressure of 0.14MPa, the polymerization started after opening the sealed catalyst tube. Thus, the catalysts and monomer simultaneously interacted in the presence of cocatalyst during the polymerization stage. The entire polymerization was carried out at 90°C for 1h. An on-line mass flow meter (Brooks SAL5800E) recorded the real-time ethylene consumption profile. At last, the polymerization was terminated by the addition of 200mL ethanol/HCl solution and the polymers were collected. In the ethylene polymerization at high pressure, another 0.5 L volume stainless-steel autoclave equipped with a mechanical stirrer, a manometer, a thermocouple, an external heating and cooling jackets and a device for breaking catalyst bottle was used for ethylene polymerization. About 100mg catalyst was also previously weighted and sealed into a small ampoule bottle in the glove box and then fixed in the interior of the reactor. The reactor was vacuumed and purged by nitrogen keeping at 90°C by a silicone oil bath with thermostat for 1.5h. Then 200mL n-heptane was pressed from the storage tank into the reactor at ethylene pressure of about 0.15MPa by using above 0.15MPa nitrogen and a certain amount of TEA (Al/Cr molar ratio=15) was also injected into the reactor with mechanically stirring. Thereafter, the temperature of the reactor was adjusted to a certain polymerization temperature such as 70°C, 80°C or 90°C and then the entire reactor was kept at that temperature and ethylene pressure of about 0.15MPa. Until the solution was saturated at a certain higher ethylene pressure such as 0.3MPa, 0.5MPa or 0.7MPa, the polymerization was initiated by breaking catalyst bottle and carried out at that polymerization temperature as mentioned above for 1h. The real-time ethylene consumption profile was also recorded by an on-line mass flow meter (Brooks SAL5851). Finally, the polymerization was terminated by adding 200mL ethanol/HCl solution and the polymers were collected. All the obtained polymers as mentioned above were washed again with ethanol, filtered out from the solution and dried under vacuum at 60°C for at least 6h. About 6mg polyethylene sample was weighted and then heated to 150°C at the rate of 10°C/min for 5min to remove thermal history, then cooled down to 50°C at 10°C/min and finally heated to 150°C at 10°C/min by DSC analyzer (TA, DSC Q200) to record the second heating curve and melting temperature (T m). The enthalpy of fusion (ΔH f) of each sample was calculated by this DSC curve. The MW and MWD of polymers were measured by high temperature gel permeation chromatography (HT-GPC, PL-220) with PL-Mixed B gel column at 140°C and the flow rate of 1.0mL/min. 1,2,4-Trichlorobenzene (TCB) and polystyrene (PS) were used as solvent and standard sample, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The characterization of catalysts It has been widely accepted that the catalytic performance of catalyst largely depends on its preparation process and conditions. Before the catalyst was used, it is important to first characterize it and investigate the influence of preparation condition on the nature of catalyst. In this work, several vital preparation conditions of the catalyst were investigated by the subsequent three characterization methods. Firstly, in order to investigate the influence of addition amount of CrBC on the supporting of chromium in different chromium catalysts, ICP characterization was used to characterize the chromium loadings of Phillips, HCat-1, HCat-2, HCat-3 and S-2 catalysts. The results showed that when the relative addition amount of CrBC was 0, 20wt% and 50wt% with 0.5wt% Crtotal loading, all the relative Cr loading loss after washing were zero as shown in Table 1 . But with further increasing the relative addition amount of CrBC to 80wt% and 100wt%, the relative Cr loading loss after washing increased to 7% and 18%, respectively. This result suggested that when the relative addition amount of CrBC was above 50wt% with 0.5wt% Crtotal loading, BC could not be fully supported. There were two assumptions to explain this phenomenon. Firstly, the main reason might be the steric hindrance effect. This is because the triphenysilyl group of the precursor had a fairly large steric hindrance effect when BC was supported on the silica gel to form the silyl chromate precursor. With raising the relative addition amount of CrBC, this steric hindrance effect became dominant so as to hinder the further supporting of BC. Secondly, the amount of byproduct TPS should be also increased with raising the addition amount of CrBC, which might facilitate the reverse reaction during the supporting of BC as shown in Scheme 1. Therefore, the proper addition weight amount of CrBC should be ≤0.25wt%. Thereafter, ICP characterization was further used to investigate the influences of calcination temperature and Crtotal loading on the hybrid catalyst system. The two significant factors could greatly influence the residual surface hydroxyl groups in Phillips catalyst as reported in the literatures [4,5], which might also affect the supporting of BC by using the residual hydroxyl groups in the preparation of the hybrid catalyst. Hence the chromium loadings of the HCat-11, HCat-12 and HCat-13 catalysts were characterized. The results indicated that when the calcination temperature was 500°C (HCat-11) or 600°C (HCat-1) and Crtotal loading was 0.5wt%, the relative Cr loading loss after washing were both zero as shown in Table 2 . But with further raising the calcination temperature to 700°C (HCat-12) or Crtotal loading to 1.0wt% (HCat-13), the relative Cr loading loss after washing increased to 9wt% and 28wt%, respectively. This result suggested that BC also could not be fully supported at the two conditions, which might be ascribed to that raising the calcination temperature or Crtotal loading could decrease the residual surface hydroxyl group population in the Phillips catalyst. It was suggested that too high calcination temperature and Crtotal loading were not beneficial for the fully supporting of BC in the preparation of the hybrid catalyst. Therefore, the suitable calcination temperature and Crtotal loading were ≤600°C and ≤0.5wt%, respectively. Herein it was suggested that the residual surface hydroxyl group population might greatly influence the fully supporting of BC. The further characterization and investigation on the amount of residual surface hydroxyl group after the supporting of BC should be considered. In the literatures [4,30], the residual surface hydroxyl group population is a critical factor to influence the polymerization activity of Phillips and S-2 catalysts and the MW of their polymers. Subsequently, the TGA–DTA and FTIR characterizations were used to qualitatively characterize the Phillips, HCat-1, HCat-2, HCat-3 and S-2 catalysts. The TGA–DTA characterization showed that there was an obvious endothermic peak in the TGA curves b, c, d and e in Fig. 1 (before), which was mainly attributed to the oxidation of the organic silyl chromate precursor in the HCat-1, HCat-2, HCat-3 and S-2 catalysts. In this work, the color of the four catalysts after heating in the TGA–DTA characterization was found to be changed from light brown to yellow, which suggested a full oxidation of the organic silyl chromate precursor at high temperature. This was consistent with a previous report by Gaspar et al. [40–42] that Phillips catalyst could be prepared using BC as precursor salt. But there also appeared an apparent broad shoulder peak after 400°C in curves d and e in Fig. 1 (before), which might be caused by the vaporization of the byproduct TPS (boiling point at 389°C) or removing the residual surface hydroxyl groups in the catalyst. In order to further explain this phenomenon, HMDS was used to remove the residual hydroxyl groups [43] (Scheme 3A) and react with residual TPS in the catalyst system (Scheme 3B). Similarly, DesLauriers et al. [44] used (CH3)3SiCl to characterize the different types of hydroxyl group on aluminophosphate supported Phillips catalyst by 29Si solid state NMR. After the five catalysts reacted with HMDS, they were measured again by TGA–DTA characterization. First of all, since there was no endothermic peak at 126°C (the boiling point of HMDS) in the five TGA curves in Fig. 1 (after), it was confirmed that no residual HMDS was in the catalyst systems after the reaction. Secondly, after a comparison of curves a in both Fig. 1 (before) and Fig. 1 (after), it was found that there appeared an endothermic peak at about 350°C in Fig. 1 (after). This peak should be derived from the oxidization of the methyl groups under air, which suggested that HMDS did react with the residual surface hydroxyl groups in the Phillips catalyst. Thirdly, the broad shoulder peak in curve e in Fig. 1 (before) still appeared in that of Fig. 1 (after) and even became more apparent. In the S-2 catalyst system, HMDS could react with not only the residual hydroxyl groups, but also TPS to produce 1,1,1-trimethyl-3,3,3-triphenyldisiloxane with much lower boiling point (∼349°C [45]) compared with that of TPS. Hence it was reasonable to point out that the shoulder peak after 400°C in curve e in Fig. 1 (after) was attributed to the oxidization of methyl groups, while that in Fig. 1 (before) might be caused by removing the residual surface hydroxyl groups in the S-2 catalyst. Finally TGA–DTA characterization showed that with increasing the relative addition amount of CrBC, the board shoulder peak after 400°C in Fig. 1 (before) become more and more apparent. The endothermic peak caused by the oxidization of methyl group in Fig. 1 (after) shifted from about 350°C to above 400°C. These results suggested that the residual surface hydroxyl group population might increase with the increasing relative addition amount of CrBC. Thereafter, the IR spectra of the five catalysts after reacting with HMDS showed that with increasing the relative addition amount of CrBC, the band of 2964cm−1, 845cm−1 and 758cm−1 became stronger and stronger as shown in Fig. 2 , which belongs to the CH stretching, SiC stretching vibrations and CH3 rocking, respectively [43]. These results also suggested that the methyl group population increased with the increasing relative addition amount of CrBC, which further confirmed that the residual surface hydroxyl group population increased with the increasing relative addition amount of CrBC. The results were also consistent with the theoretical assumption that supporting one oxo chromate precursor usually needs two surface hydroxyl groups in the catalyst while supporting one silyl chromate precursor needs only one. At the same chromium loading, this could lead to higher residual hydroxyl group population after supporting the silyl chromate precursors compared with that after supporting the oxo chromate ones. As mentioned before, the residual surface hydroxyl group population could greatly influence the activity of the Phillips and S-2 catalysts and MW of their polymers. Hence its effect should be paid much attention in the subsequent polymerization with the hybrid catalysts. Herein several important influences of preparation condition on the nature of the different chromium catalysts had been discussed above through their characterization. Subsequently, the polymerization with these chromium catalysts would be further investigated. 3.2 The effect of cocatalyst on polymerization Cocatalyst is an important factor in the polymerization, which could influence the activity of catalyst and modify the polymers as well. In this work, three different cocatalysts were used with HCat-2 catalyst in the subsequent ethylene polymerization. With the increase of Al/Cr molar ratio, the activity of HCat-2 catalyst in the presence of the three cocatalysts including TEA, TIBA or MAO increased to a maximum value and then decreased as shown in Fig. 3 . This result indicated that the proper dosage of cocatalyst could enhance the activity of the hybrid catalyst. The roles of cocatalyst are known to be able to reduce the active precursor, alkylate the active site to initiate the first polymer chain and remove the poisons such as oxygen, moisture or byproducts [5]. But too large dosage of cocatalyst could lead to deactivation of the active site through over-reduction and also enhancement of the chain transfer reaction to cocatalyst, which was not beneficial for increasing the activity of the catalyst and the MW of its polymers. Moreover in order to get higher activity, larger dosage of MAO was needed compared with that of TEA or TIBA. This is because that MAO was a cocatalyst with relatively weaker reducing and alkylating power for the hybrid catalyst. In order to further investigate the effect of cocatalyst on the polymerization behavior of HCat-2 catalyst and its polymers, the activities of HCat-2 catalyst with the three cocatalysts, the microstructures of their polymers and their kinetics curves are illustrated in Table 3 and Fig. 4 , respectively. Their kinetic curves suggested that polymerization behavior with the three cocatalysts was similar, which was composed of two basic types of polymerization behavior. One was fast formation and fast decay and the other was slow formation and slow decay. Similar kinetic results were also reported in our previous work [46,47] in investigating the ethylene polymerization with Phillips catalyst by introducing various Al-alkyl cocatalysts with simultaneous interaction of catalyst with cocatalyst and monomer during the polymerization stage. It was suggested that these two types of polymerization behavior corresponded to two kinds of active sites, which were formed from surface chromate species through the reduction by ethylene monomer and Al-alkyl cocatalyst, respectively. Similarly, it was inferred that there might also exist two kinds of active sites: a fast formation and fast decay type (Site A1 and Site A2) and a slow formation and slow decay type (Site B1 and Site B2) in the ethylene polymerization with the hybrid catalyst. The plausible mechanism of the formation of two kinds of Cr active site precursors is illustrated in Scheme 4 , which was based on our previous mechanistical speculation [46,47]. Firstly according to our previous work [48,49] and the literatures [5,26–28], the surface oxo and silyl chromate species in the hybrid catalyst system after its preparation should be Cr(VI) species. The oxo and silyl chromate Cr(VI) species could be reduced by ethylene monomer to Cr(II) species, then Cr(II) species were coordinated with formaldehyde (named as Site C1 and Site C2, respectively, the precursors of Site C1 and Site C2 are shown in Scheme 4) which is the byproduct of reaction between ethylene and surface chromate species. Subsequently, Site A1 and Site A2 were formed through desorption of formaldehyde from Site C1 and Site C2, respectively, by Al-alkyl cocatalyst such as TEA, TIBA or MAO. Site A1 and Site A2 were very exposed and can be easily coordinated with ethylene monomer showing higher initial activity; On the other hand, they could be also easily over-reduced by Al-alkyl cocatalyst leading to the faster decay. Secondly, some oxo and silyl chromate Cr(VI) species were reduced by Al-alkyl cocatalyst and then coordinated with Al-alkoxy by-product resulting in Site B1 and Site B2 (Scheme 4), respectively. Site B1 and Site B2 are Cr(II) species strongly coordinated with Al-alkoxy, which are formed by oxidation of Al-alkyl cocatalyst with surface oxo and silyl chromate species. Thus Site B1 and Site B2 were protected from further over-reduction by Al-alkyl cocatalyst and influenced by electron donating of Al-alkoxy. They had lower activity and higher stability compared with Site A1 and Site A2. So it could be summarized that the two kinds of Cr active sites (Site A1 and Site A2, Site B1 and Site B2) were derived from the surface oxo and silyl chromate Cr(VI) species through the reduction by monomer and Al-alkyl cocatalyst, respectively. By further comparing their kinetic curves, the curve with TEA as cocatalyst decayed more rapidly than those with the other two cocatalysts. This is because that TEA with fairly strong reducing and alkylating power for the hybrid catalyst might over-reduce the active site so as to result in the faster decay. On the other hand, after comparing the GPC results of their polymers, it was found that the average MW of polymer with TEA was lower than that with TIBA at the same dosage of cocatalyst as shown in Table 3 and Fig. 5 . This suggested that TEA had larger effect on chain transfer compared with TIBA. The MWD of polymer with MAO was the broadest in that of the three polymers. This might be due to MAO as a mixture of methylaluminoxanes with various molecular weights, which owns different reducing and alkylating power to produce various active sites with different chain propagation and chain transfer rates for the hybrid catalyst. Up to now, the influences of the three cocatalysts on the ethylene polymerization with the hybrid catalyst were fully investigated. TEA as a commonly used cocatalyst was used with Al/Cr molar ratio at 15 in the subsequent ethylene and ethylene/1-hexene polymerization with the different chromium catalysts. 3.3 The polymerization behavior of different chromium catalysts Since the previous ICP characterization suggested that the relative addition amount of CrBC could influence the fully supporting of BC, it might further influence the polymerization behavior of HCat-1, HCat-2, HCat-3 catalysts and the microstructures of their polymers. The three catalysts with the Phillips and S-2 catalysts as references were compared in the subsequent ethylene and ethylene/1-hexene polymerization. In the ethylene polymerization at 0.14MPa, when the relative addition amount of CrBC increased from 0 to 20wt%, the activity of HCat-1 catalyst decreased compared with that of Phillips catalyst as shown in Table 4 , but with further increasing the relative addition amount of CrBC to 50wt%, 80wt% and 100wt% respectively, the activities of the HCat-2, HCat-3 and S-2 catalysts were all close to that of HCat-1 catalyst with only a slight decreasing tendency. On the other hand, the kinetic curves of the five catalysts as shown in Fig. 6 suggested that the polymerization behavior of the five catalysts was similar to that of HCat-2 catalyst in the presence of cocatalyst, which was also composed of two basic types of polymerization behavior as mentioned before. When the ethylene pressure was raised from 0.14MPa to 0.3MPa, the activities of the five catalysts significantly increased as shown in Table 4 because raising the ethylene concentration facilitated the chain propagation. Their kinetic curves were still similar to those at 0.14MPa. Herein with increasing the relative addition amount of CrBC, the activities of the five catalysts showed an apparent decreasing tendency. There were three assumptions to explain this phenomenon. Firstly, the main reason was that with the increasing relative addition amount of CrBC the practical weight amount of CrBC and Cr from Phillips catalyst in the five catalysts increased and decreased, respectively. Because the activity of the Phillips catalyst was much higher than that of the S-2 catalyst especially in the polymerization at 0.3MPa, hence the weight amount of Cr from Phillips catalyst in the catalyst system must play the dominant role for the activity of the catalyst. Secondly, with the increasing relative addition amount of CrBC, the residual hydroxyl group population also increased, which further declined the activity of Cr active site from the Phillips catalyst. In the literatures [4], the gradual increase of activity of the Phillips catalyst by raising the calcination temperature was mainly attributed to the decrease of residual surface hydroxyl groups in the catalyst system. Thirdly, BC could not be fully supported when the relative addition amount of CrBC was above 0.25wt%, which leads to decreasing the activity of the silyl Cr active site. Although Baker and Carrick [24–27] reported that BC could also polymerize ethylene at high ethylene pressure or at atmospheric pressure with cocatalyst such as TEA to produce polyethylene with high MW, it showed much lower activity compared with that after supporting on silica gel. In order to further compare the polymerization behavior of the five catalysts, the microstructures of their polymers were also characterized as shown in Table 4 and Fig. 7 . With increasing the relative addition amount of CrBC, the average MW of the five polymers showed an increasing tendency at both 0.14MPa and 0.3MPa. The GPC curves of their polymers at 0.3MPa reflected that the high and low MW parts of the polymers showed an increasing and decreasing tendency, respectively. By comparing the five catalysts, HCat-2 catalyst showed well-balanced properties in the aspect of ethylene polymerization, because it showed much higher activity than S-2 catalyst in the ethylene polymerization at 0.3MPa, its polymer also showed much higher average MW and broader MWD than those obtained from the Phillips catalyst. Although HCat-1 catalyst showed much higher activity than HCat-2 catalyst at 0.3MPa, the average MW of its polymer was lower than that obtained from HCat-2 catalyst. Its polymer had much more low MW tail and less high MW materials than that obtained from HCat-2 catalyst at 0.3MPa. Generally speaking, HCat-1 catalyst was more similar to Phillips catalyst in the aspect of polymerization behavior and the microstructures of their polymers. Moreover, HCat-3 catalyst was very similar to S-2 catalyst. It could be suggested that adding too less or too much BC in the catalyst preparation was not beneficial for the hybrid catalyst to get the well-balanced properties. Thereafter in order to investigate the difference between the hybridization of Phillips and S-2 catalysts and the mechanically mixing of these two catalysts, Cat-M catalyst was compared with HCat-2, Phillips and S-2 catalysts in the ethylene polymerization. The results showed that although polymerization behavior of HCat-2 and Cat-M catalysts was similar at both 0.14MPa and 0.3MPa as shown in Fig. 6, the average MW and MWD of their polymers were significantly different as shown in Table 4 and Fig. 7. Generally speaking, in the polymerization at 0.14MPa, the average MW and MWD of their polymers were both between those obtained from Phillips and S-2 catalysts. But in the polymerization at 0.3MPa, the average MW of polymers obtained from Cat-M catalyst greatly increased compared with that at 0.14MPa. It was much higher than that obtained from HCat-2 catalyst and even slightly higher than that obtained from S-2 catalyst. This result suggested that raising the ethylene concentration might enhance the effect of silyl Cr active site on the MW of its polymer in the Cat-M catalyst system. On the other hand, in the ethylene/1-hexene copolymerization, with increasing the relative addition amount of CrBC, the activities of Phillips, HCat-1, HCat-2, HCat-3 and S-2 catalysts and the average MW of their copolymers showed a decreasing and increasing tendency, respectively as illustrated in Table 4 and Fig. 8 . These results were similar to those in the ethylene homopolymerization with the five catalysts, which might be also explained by the three factors as mentioned before. The DSC characterization results of their copolymers showed that with increasing the relative addition amount of CrBC, their T m gradually increased and shifted to the higher temperature region and the ΔH f also gradually increased as shown in Table 4 and Fig. 9 . This might be ascribed to that less and less short chain branches in the backbone of polymer that excluded from the crystalline regions were produced by the insertion of 1-hexene, thus resulting in a decrease of the fraction of polymer that is amorphous [5]. This result might suggest that with the increasing relative addition amount of CrBC, the copolymerization abilities of the five catalysts also showed a decreasing tendency. The result was also consistent with Cann's results about copolymerization abilities of the Phillip and S-2 catalysts [5,28]. By comparing the five catalysts, it was suggested that HCat-1 catalyst was more similar to Phillips catalyst in the aspect of copolymerization ability and the microstructures of their copolymers. HCat-2 catalyst was between Phillips and S-2 catalysts and slightly close to S-2 catalyst, while HCat-3 catalyst was much more similar to S-2 catalyst. Although the activity of Cat-M catalyst was slightly higher than that of HCat-2 catalyst, the average MW of its copolymer was much lower than that obtained from HCat-2 catalyst, which was more similar to that obtained from the Phillips or HCat-1 catalyst. But the ΔH f of its copolymer was slightly higher than that of copolymer obtained from HCat-2 catalyst. These results suggested that Cat-M and HCat-2 catalysts were totally different in the aspect of ethylene/1-hexene copolymerization. 3.4 The effects of calcination temperature and Crtotal loading Since the previous ICP characterization also suggested that too high calcination temperature and Crtotal loading were not beneficial for the fully supporting of BC in the preparation of the hybrid catalyst, it might further influence the polymerization behavior of HCat-11, HCat-12 and HCat-13 catalysts and the microstructures of their polymers. The three catalysts and HCat-1 catalyst were compared in the subsequent ethylene polymerization. With raising the calcination temperature or Crtotal loading, the activities of the four catalysts showed a decreasing tendency as shown in Table 5 . There were two assumptions to explain this phenomenon. Firstly, when the calcination temperature or Crtotal loading was 700°C or 1.0wt%, respectively, BC could not be fully supported as suggested by the previous ICP characterization. The residual free BC in the hybrid catalyst system showed much lower polymerization activity in the presence of TEA compared with that after supporting, but its polymer had high MW as mentioned before. This assumption explained that with raising the calcination temperature from 600°C to 700°C or Crtotal loading from 0.5wt% to 1.0wt%, HCat-12 and HCat-13 catalysts showed much lower activities compared with HCat-1 catalyst, but the average MW of their polymers were slightly higher than that obtained from HCat-1 catalyst as shown in Table 5. However, the first assumption mentioned above could not explain that with raising the calcination temperature from 500°C to 600°C, the activity of HCat-11 catalyst and the average MW of its polymer were also slightly higher and lower than those of HCat-1 catalyst and its polymer, respectively. As suggested by the previous ICP characterization, the relative Cr loading loss after washing of the above two catalysts were both zero, and BC were fully supported in the two catalysts. The second assumption might explain this phenomenon, which was the influence of residual hydroxyl group on silyl Cr active site in the hybrid catalyst system. In the patent, Carrick et al. [23] once reported that with raising the calcination temperature of silica gel support, the activity of commercial S-2 catalyst and MI of its ethylene/1-butune copolymer greatly decreased in the presence of cocatalyst. Meanwhile, in our previous work [30] about silyl chromate catalyst system, it was suggested that the neighboring hydroxyl group next to the silyl Cr active site was favorable to the polymerization activity, because it created electron-withdrawing effect and was beneficial to the ethylene insertion. This case was quite different with the case of the Phillips catalyst. Therefore, it could be similarly inferred that with raising the calcination temperature or Crtotal loading, the residual hydroxyl group population in the hybrid catalyst system decreased. This further leaded to decreasing the possibility of forming the neighboring hydroxyl group next to silyl Cr active site so as to decrease the activity of catalyst and increase the average MW of its polymer. It could be summarized that too high calcination temperature and Crtotal loading were not beneficial not only for the fully supporting of BC, but also for enhancing the activity of the hybrid catalyst. The suitable calcination temperature and Crtotal loading should be ≤600°C and ≤0.5wt%, respectively. 3.5 The effects of polymerization temperature, pressure and hydrogen Polymerization temperature, pressure and hydrogen are three important factors to greatly influence the activity of catalyst and the MW of its polymer. In this work, the three factors were varied in the subsequent ethylene polymerization by using HCat-2 catalyst. Firstly, with gradually raising the polymerization temperature from 70°C to 90°C, the activity of HCat-2 catalyst was kept decreasing as shown in Table 6 , which might be due to that raising the temperature was not beneficial for the dissolution of ethylene monomer in the solvent. Since in this work the polymerization pressure was relatively low, raising the temperature might largely decrease the ethylene concentration in the solvent, particularly when the temperature was 90°C. The subsequent GPC characterization indicated that the average MW and MWD of its polymers also gradually decreased with the raising polymerization temperature. The low MW tail of the polymers gradually reduced and a part of middle MW materials shifted to lower MW region as shown in Fig. 10 . This is because raising the polymerization temperature usually facilitated the chain transfer much more compared with chain propagation [5]. Secondly with gradually raising the ethylene pressure from 0.14MPa to 0.7MPa, the activity of HCat-2 catalyst was kept increasing, but the average MW of its polymers at the four different ethylene pressures were very similar as shown in Table 6. This phenomenon might be due to that raising the ethylene concentration in the hybrid catalyst system could facilitate both the chain propagation and the chain transfer to the incoming monomer in the nearly same extent. Compared with the chain transfer to active site and Al-alkyl cocatalyst, the chain transfer to monomer might be the main chain transfer reaction in the polymerization [5]. Finally, the activity of HCat-2 catalyst with the addition of hydrogen slightly decreased than that without H2 addition as shown in Table 7 . In the literatures, the influence of hydrogen on the activity of catalyst had been widely reported, which was so-called “hydrogen effect”. But until now the hydrogen effect was still very difficult to be fully understood and explained well because it behaves in various aspects depending on the polymerization condition and the catalyst type. It was reported that the activity of catalyst increased with the addition of hydrogen in the propylene polymerization by using Ti-based Ziegler–Natta catalyst [50,51]. The phenomenon is usually explained by hydrogenolysis of dormant active centers formed after secondary insertion of a propylene molecule into the growing polymer chain [50,51]. However, it was also reported that the activity of catalyst decreased with the addition of hydrogen in the ethylene polymerization by using the same catalyst. Kissin et al. explained that the addition of hydrogen increased the concentration of TiC2H5 species that was not beneficial for the next insertion step because of its β-H agostic effect [52,53]. In the investigation of ethylene polymerization with the Phillips catalyst in the presence of hydrogen, McDaniel et al. [5] found that the activity of catalyst decreased with the addition of hydrogen. They explained that hydrogen could also reduce oxo chromate precursors to produce byproduct water, and water as a strong poison usually leaded to the immediate deactivation of Cr active site thus resulting in decreasing the activity of Phillips catalyst. In this work, our case is similar to McDaniel's. The subsequent GPC characterization showed that with the addition of hydrogen, the average MW of its polymer also decreased and the MWD greatly broadened as shown in Table 7. The GPC curves illustrated that with the addition of hydrogen the MW of its polymer shifted to the lower MW region and the high MW materials decreased as shown in Fig. 11 . These results were attributed to that hydrogen as a strong chain transfer reagent could decrease the MW of polymer. 4 Conclusion In this work, a novel SiO2-supported inorganic and organic hybrid chromium-based catalyst for ethylene and ethylene/1-hexene polymerization was successfully synthesized by using the residual surface hydroxyl groups in Phillips catalyst to support BC. This catalyst was prepared through hybridizing two important industrial chromium-based catalysts namely inorganic Phillips and organic S-2 catalysts in order to get the merits from each catalyst system. By characterization of the catalysts, investigation of the polymerization behavior and the microstructures of polymers, several vital factors such as cocatalyst, the addition amount of BC, calcination temperature, Crtotal loading, polymerization temperature, pressure and hydrogen, which could influence the properties of the hybrid catalyst system, were systematically investigated. For the catalyst preparation, the proper addition weight amount of BC was CrBC ≤0.25wt%. The suitable calcination temperature and Crtotal loading were ≤ 600°C and ≤0.5wt%, respectively. As for the polymerization, the proper dosage of Al-alkyl cocatalyst such as TEA, TIBA and MAO could enhance the activity of HCat-2 catalyst. There might exist two kinds of Cr active sites (Site A1 and Site A2, Site B1 and Site B2), which were corresponding to the two types of polymerization kinetics (fast formation and fast decay, slow formation and slow decay), and they might be formed through the reducing of surface chromate Cr(VI) species by ethylene monomer and cocatalyst, respectively. With increasing the relative addition amount of CrBC from 0 to 20, 50, 80 and 100wt% (corresponding from Phillips to HCat-1, HCat-2, HCat-3 and S-2 catalysts), the copolymerization abilities of the catalysts showed a decreasing tendency. Through the comparison of different chromium catalysts, it was found that HCat-2 catalyst showed higher activity than S-2 catalyst and its polymer had higher average MW, boarder MWD than that obtained from the Phillips catalyst. HCat-2 catalyst got well-balanced properties mainly including activity, MW of polymers and copolymerization ability. Moreover, adding hydrogen or raising the polymerization temperature from 70°C to 90°C could decrease the activity of HCat-2 catalyst and the average MW of its polymers. But raising the ethylene pressure from 0.14MPa to 0.7MPa greatly enhanced the activity of the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: In this work, a novel SiO2-supported hybrid chromium-based catalyst for ethylene and ethylene/1-hexene polymerization was prepared by using the residual surface hydroxyl groups in Phillips catalyst to further support bis(triphenysilyl) chromate (BC) in order to get the merits from two important chromium-based catalysts namely inorganic Phillips and organic S-2 catalysts. By characterization of the catalysts, investigation of the polymerization behavior and the microstructures of polymers, several vital factors such as cocatalyst, the addition amount of BC, calcination temperature, total chromium loading, polymerization temperature, pressure and hydrogen were systematically investigated. The proper addition weight amount of BC was CrBC ≤0.25wt%. The suitable calcination temperature and total chromium loading were ≤600°C and ≤0.5wt%, respectively. With increasing the relative addition amount of CrBC from 0 to 20, 50, 80 and 100wt% (corresponding from Phillips to HCat-1, HCat-2, HCat-3 and S-2 catalysts), the copolymerization abilities of the above catalysts showed a decreasing tendency. By comparing different chromium catalysts, HCat-2 catalyst showed higher activity than S-2 catalyst and its polymer had higher average molecular weight (MW) than that obtained from Phillips catalyst. HCat-2 catalyst got well-balanced properties mainly including activity, MW of polymers and copolymerization ability.
coredata.dc:title: A novel SiO2-supported inorganic and organic hybrid chromium-based catalyst for ethylene polymerization
